Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Development and Application of Direct Dynamics Simulations for Studying the Fragmentation and Reaction of Biological Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program, the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods (CTMC) Program and the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor William Hase of Texas Tech University, his French collaborators (funded by the ANR) and Texas Tech University post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate student researchers are conducting computational studies of the ways that biomolecular ions react in the gas phase. These studies will help to inform scientists who are using mass spectrometry methods to analyze the composition of complicated mixtures of biomolecules ? a ubiquitous problem in the biosciences. Post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students working on this project will receive world-class training in computational chemistry, while working with young scientists from France.

Prof. William Hase will collaborate with Prof. Riccardo Spezia from CNRS, Laboratoire Analyse et Modelisation pour Biologie et l?Environment. The US and French research groups are conducting a multi-pronged research effort investigating the reactions and dynamics of biomolecules in the gas phase. The two groups will: (1) model tandem mass spectrometry experiments of the fragmentation of peptides, carbohydrates and steroids; (2) model the gas-phase production of biomolecules from precursor species. The young researchers working on this project will receive excellent technical training, and will work alongside some of the best French researchers in this field. The software that is developed in this project will be incorporated into existing software packages that are used by a wide range of researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the work supported by this grant chemical dynamics computer simulations methods were developed and applied to study: (1) the fragmentation of biological ions, in particular peptide ions, in mass spectrometry experiments; and (2) reaction schemes for forming biological ions in the interstellar medium. The former is an analytical technique to determine the primary structure of peptide ions, i.e  their sequence of amino acids. This sequence/structure determines their biological function.  In mass spectrometry experiments biological ions are fragmented by gas-phase collisions with an unreactive projectile like the nitrogen molecule, N2, or the argon atom, Ar. The fragment ions formed by these colliosions may be identified by mass spectrometry and then may be "patched back together" to determine the primary structure of the ion. In studies of biological systems, such as cells, molecules are identifed and their masses can be easily determined. However, often their primary structures are not known and this mass spectrometry technique  may be the most important way to determine these structures. The computer simulations modeled these experiments and gave an accurate determination of the ions which are formed. The simulations allow the study of biological ions which are hard to analyze experimentally. The simulations also describe the mechanisms for forming the ions, which gave a fundamental understanding for the fragementations leading to the ion formation. Excitation of the ions by collision in the experiments adds energy to the ion  in specifice non-random ways, much different than simply thermally heating the ion. The simulations showed that this collision excitation leads to different fragmentation mechanisms than found by thermal heating. This finding led to a deeper fundamental understanding of models for collisional fragmentation of biological ions. Reaction mechanism were identified which may form biological ions in the interstellar medium, which may be important components for the formation of living organisms. Mechanisms with very large energy barriers are required.


Last Modified: 06/26/2018
Modified by: William L Hase
